ariaShowSolution: Show the solution. You will be provided with a sample solution.

taskDescription:
A crafter uses four letter-size sheets of paper to create a paper mosaic in the shape of a square. They decide they want to frame the paper mosaic, so they measure and determine that the area of the paper mosaic is <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow>
  <msup>
    <mtext>2,412.89 cm</mtext>
    <mn>2</mn>
  </msup>
</mrow><annotation encoding="LaTeX">\text{2,412.89 cm}^2</annotation></semantics></math>. Does their calculation make sense? Explain your answer.
detailedSolution: Yes. The unit of value, cm<sup>2</sup>, is appropriate given the size of a sheet of paper. Because the total area of 2,412.89 cm<sup>2</sup> represents four sheets of paper, each sheet is approximately 600 cm<sup>2</sup>, which seems reasonable for a sheet of letter-size paper.
